{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3344116,"name":"","username":"nstrike","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T15:24:58.528Z","cooked":"

Over the weekend I saw many many many faikures of CAN connections, fortunately these have gotten significantly easier to debug (thanks REV and CTRE <3) and find the bad connection quickly. However the question i kept asking myself was “How should you connect CAN lines reliably while still able to fix them when an issue occurs”.

While I like WAGO’s there were several occasions where they were the source of the problem too.

Another thing to note is slack, a properly wired CAN bus has some slack to avoid the wire coming out, and that should be taken into account, however it should also be able to be secure the connection ideally in both ends (although a planned failure point is appreciated from a certain perspective).

This is separate from CAN star which if implemented right is amazing but alot of teams are unable to implement it correctly.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-03-26T15:25:34.538Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":62,"reads":297,"readers_count":296,"score":379.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":460195,"topic_slug":"can-connection-preferences","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining/504771/2","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"What are your experiences with CAN topologies other than Daisy-chaining?","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51887,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"YAGSL & YASS Creator "},"post_url":"/t/can-connection-preferences/460195/1","custom_user_title":"YAGSL & YASS Creator ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3344125,"name":"Random Guy","username":"Random_Guy1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/a183cd/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T15:28:40.706Z","cooked":"

Unless you are keeping your stub lengths within the max allowed by the CANBus specification, star topology is a violation of how the specification calls for it to be wired. You can get away with it with the CAN 2.0 bus on the RoboRIO, but CAN FD is not nearly as tolerant of such shenanigans.

For connectors my team uses Molex SL, with the crimper that was available through FIRST Choice. It is excellent, makes it very easy to make good terminations.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-03-26T15:28:40.706Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":289,"readers_count":288,"score":107.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":460195,"topic_slug":"can-connection-preferences","display_username":"Random Guy","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16305,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2974 Walton Robotics Electrical Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/can-connection-preferences/460195/2","custom_user_title":"2974 Walton Robotics Electrical Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3344164,"name":"Drakxii","username":"Drakxii","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/4da419/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T15:52:49.848Z","cooked":"

I prefer to cut off the molex, crimp on ferules and then use knock off wagos, i prefer the inline ones that lock together.

If I were a richer team, I would probably just solder splice them all but we can’t afford to replace the spark max wires every year.

Team 2102 recently switched to using automotive DEUTSCH DTM connectors and we’ve been really happy with them. Additionally, we swapped to trunk-and-branch CAN topology this year (thats not the official name) and have been having great success with it.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-03-26T15:55:42.658Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":248,"readers_count":247,"score":104.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":460195,"topic_slug":"can-connection-preferences","display_username":"Aiden L","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53542,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Trade shirts with me!"},"post_url":"/t/can-connection-preferences/460195/5","custom_user_title":"Trade shirts with me!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3344227,"name":"Nick Foote","username":"Footie","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/footie/{size}/218325_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T16:43:00.219Z","cooked":"

I just wanted to add more onto this, here’s a great diagram of what they did:

Wiring Poster1920×1440 173 KB

One of our biggest pain points in the past was, having a motor out on an intake and getting the exposed can wire chopped, and then we were just done. It allows for a protected main CAN run, and stubs off of that, so that we could lose any motor and it would not impact the others. In fact, you could rip the entire pivot/shooter/intake off our robot, and we’d still be able to drive.

Thankfully this year we didn’t have some massive extension out of our robot (like last year) that meant the main trunk had to be exposed (because stub length is very short).

I had tried this methodology with my team last year and unfortunately didn’t follow the stub length rules well. I will try it again in the future but i find this in theory to be the most robust solution

One thing you have to do, that feels incredibly wrong, is snip the other end of the CAN on the motor controller very short. Because that length is part of the stub, and having it long will give you problems.

image1254×1368 174 KB

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-03-26T16:52:20.265Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":204,"readers_count":203,"score":65.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":460195,"topic_slug":"can-connection-preferences","display_username":"Nick Foote","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/7/0/70ead5c8b362192dda5ad05af851be76b1b38001.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":51887,"username":"nstrike","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":8103,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Nick Foote - 2102 Team Paradox - Engineering Mentor and Founding Student"},"post_url":"/t/can-connection-preferences/460195/8","custom_user_title":"Nick Foote - 2102 Team Paradox - Engineering Mentor and Founding Student","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3344240,"name":"Brian Rozmierski","username":"bdaroz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bdaroz/{size}/128636_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T16:59:08.585Z","cooked":"
nstrike:

While I like WAGO’s there were several occasions where they were the source of the problem too.

In-Line WAGOs have been a problem this season at every event I’ve been at. Take your pick:

  • Connecting a swerve drive motor
  • Connecting CAN bus wires

For the former I’ve seen 2 melted WAGOs, and heard of or seen pictures of at least 5-6 more now.

CAN-wise I can’t count how many teams with CAN errors we’ve traced to in-line WAGOs.

Regardless of Youtube videos and whatnot, understand the manufacturer does not support those in-line WAGOs in either of those use cases. In the first, the WAGO is rated for 32A, not 40A. In the 2nd, the CAN wire is smaller than the minimum rated wire for the WAGO.

Now will it work in both of those cases? There is enough evidence to say yes, with one very large caveat.

YOU HAVE TO USE THEM CORRECTLY

That means, proper cut ends (flush and perpendicular to the cable, especially for the 12 AWG wires), proper stripping of the sheathing (there is a guide on the side of the in-line WAGO), and full, but not over, insertion.

Melted WAGOs were tinned, incorrectly cut (at an angle), or twisted. Failed CAN were under/over stripped, or overly inserted such that the wire was curled inside the WAGO and the busbar contacted the sheathing.

And yes, all of this still includes the need for proper wire management and relief - something many teams still struggle with.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-03-26T16:59:08.585Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":187,"readers_count":186,"score":52.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":460195,"topic_slug":"can-connection-preferences","display_username":"Brian Rozmierski","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":27012,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC Volunteer / Former 5881 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/can-connection-preferences/460195/9","custom_user_title":"FRC Volunteer / Former 5881 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3344251,"name":"","username":"Vasista","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/v/ccd318/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T17:08:38.831Z","cooked":"

You probably could have gotten away with keeping the wire if you had extended the trunk by ~2ft before the terminating resistor.

Why is star topology the only can bus topology CD ever talks about? Trunk and branch exists and works fine on both the Rio bus and the can fd bus.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-03-26T17:16:54.980Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":165,"readers_count":164,"score":68.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":460195,"topic_slug":"can-connection-preferences","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":16305,"username":"Random_Guy1","name":"Random Guy","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/a183cd/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":39370,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5940 | 4096 | WPILib and Robotpy Developer"},"post_url":"/t/can-connection-preferences/460195/11","custom_user_title":"5940 | 4096 | WPILib and Robotpy Developer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3344291,"name":"Jai Gupta","username":"jaigupta13","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/4da419/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T17:25:10.793Z","cooked":"

We have had great experience with Molex SL and recommend it to all teams looking to improve reliability. Details are on our build thread.

FRC 3061 Huskie Robotics - 2024 Season Build Thread Open Alliance
CAN and Low Power Connector Solution What connector to use for CAN is a perennial question. Our answer is Molex SL. We have had 100% reliability since we were introduced to Molex SL connectors around 3 years ago. Not one crimp has failed in over a thousand. We achieve this through solid part selection, training, procedure, and inspection. Part selection: The crimper we use is part 638118700. We recommend the official crimper for the best crimps. You can get the crimper in the FIRST Choice Molex…

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-03-26T17:32:28.200Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":152,"readers_count":151,"score":30.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":460195,"topic_slug":"can-connection-preferences","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":8103,"username":"Footie","name":"Nick Foote","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/footie/{size}/218325_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51887,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"YAGSL & YASS Creator "},"post_url":"/t/can-connection-preferences/460195/13","custom_user_title":"YAGSL & YASS Creator ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3344307,"name":"Technologyman00","username":"Technologyman00","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/technologyman00/{size}/178178_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T17:39:00.959Z","cooked":"
nstrike:

WAGO’s there were several occasions where they were the source of the problem too.

7900 uses a mix of the inline WAGOs and Anderson’s. If we need to extend anything past the Rev CAN cables we cut off the Anderson’s and put on WAGOs. We currently don’t use clear WAGOs so it’s hard to say whether or not it makes a good connection. A pull test can usually sus out the bad connections but after we do a run down of the robot and test it out we were able to work out any poor connections. And thankfully (knock on every plank of wood) we haven’t had any CAN issues at our competitions

We also keep a list of how the line of CAN devices are wired so we can look at the CAN errors and narrow down the problematic connection to 1 or 2 connectors. I have always wanted the Code to do this automatically as it should be a pretty easy but super useful piece of code but we’ve never gotten around to it

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-03-26T17:41:20.171Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":153,"readers_count":152,"score":45.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":460195,"topic_slug":"can-connection-preferences","display_username":"Technologyman00","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25951,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7900, 1792, 1714"},"post_url":"/t/can-connection-preferences/460195/14","custom_user_title":"7900, 1792, 1714","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3344336,"name":"Aiden L","username":"Baby_Carrot","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/baby_carrot/{size}/203814_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T18:08:46.166Z","cooked":"

Not quite, you can’t see it on the robot, but that motor is ~11in out from the main branch of the CANBus. Keeping that wire any longer would make our branch overly long for spec. If we were to move our branch closer to the motor so that both CAN leads were the same length (or whatever length you want), the trunk becomes highly exposed. We found that having just the one long CAN lead and one just long enough for an emergency crimp gave the best balance of reliability and ease of installment.

I get that. I’m saying you could have gotten away with the longer ~24" branch if you extended the trunk. Or 18" and had a nice solid 6" of wire left on the motor controller for future use. It’s all ymmv

I believe this basically boils down to “does the physical wiring meet the official specification?”. “Trunk and branch” sounds like in-spec CAN bus wiring with stub lengths that are longer than just the PCB traces, but less than the 12 inch limit of the specification. Star topology would be an out-of-spec wiring with the stub lengths being too long (and maybe something about the distance between connections?). “Daisy chain” would be, if I’m defining it, in-spec wiring with stub lengths of just the PCB traces, which is closer to the idealized topology than trunk and branch is, but the fact that they are both in-spec means that they are not often distinguished when it comes to discussions of validity.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-03-26T18:48:12.612Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":113,"readers_count":112,"score":27.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":460195,"topic_slug":"can-connection-preferences","display_username":"Gordon Walsh","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":39370,"username":"Vasista","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/v/ccd318/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26202,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5827 Mentor | he/him/his"},"post_url":"/t/can-connection-preferences/460195/17","custom_user_title":"5827 Mentor | he/him/his","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3344433,"name":"","username":"Vasista","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/v/ccd318/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T18:53:03.528Z","cooked":"

I’m more concerned with what actually works. A lot of the CAN spec is just recommendations, not electrical limits. I’ve seen 6" stubs fail and 16" stubs work. I’ve seen 1 terminating resistor fail and 2 terminating resistors work. The true end goal is to have a robust and reliable CAN bus.

edit: I understand that keeping things in spec results in a higher probability of a reliable CAN bus. But I’ve certainly been in situations where there isn’t time to redo the CAN bus correctly and it needs to be massaged.

","post_number":18,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-03-26T18:55:28.780Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":17,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":110,"readers_count":109,"score":37.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":460195,"topic_slug":"can-connection-preferences","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":26202,"username":"GordonW","name":"Gordon Walsh","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/7feea3/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":39370,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5940 | 4096 | WPILib and Robotpy Developer"},"post_url":"/t/can-connection-preferences/460195/18","custom_user_title":"5940 | 4096 | WPILib and Robotpy Developer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3344437,"name":"Nick Foote","username":"Footie","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/footie/{size}/218325_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T18:55:01.926Z","cooked":"

I’m not sure I follow. The ISO11898 Standard specifies a maximum stub length of 0.3m at 1Mbps. Increasing our trunk length doesn’t increase our maximum stub length. We could go longer than the spec, but the point of doing it this way is to battle harden our robot, so why add potential risk.

On our intake/shooter, we have the main trunk run just about to the actual outer plates, then branch. We don’t want our trunk exposed on the plates, or too close to our rollers that spin as fast as 6k rpm. So even if we brought our trunk closer to the controller, we’d be putting our main trunk in danger, thus negating the point of doing it.

image1386×955 114 KB

What I meant is it should be fine to leave a couple more inches of wire on the 2nd lead off the motor controller even if its technically out of spec so it’s easier to reuse your motor controllers for other stuff in the future (or you just want to).

I’ve had a can bus fail where the last motor was on a 12" stub. Meaning the last stub was 12" past the terminating resistor. In that case, I massaged the can bus by extending the trunk such that (length of trunk > length of last motor stub) and that made things peachy.
